title: 104_s598
content:
The Act titled "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on tobacco products. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on cigars. The amendment in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 raises the tax rate on cigars to $5.8125 per thousand and imposes a tax of 65.875 percent on large cigars weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand, capped at $155 per thousand. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" raises taxes on cigars to $5.8125 per thousand and imposes a 65.875 percent tax on large cigars over 3 pounds per thousand, capped at $155 per thousand. The tax on cigarettes is also increased to $62 per thousand. The tax rates on cigarettes are increased to $130.20 per thousand, while the tax on cigarette papers is raised to 3.875 cents. The tax rates on cigarette tubes, snuff, and chewing tobacco are amended to 7.75 cents, $1.86, and $1.86 respectively. The tax rates on smokeless tobacco products are amended to $1.86 for snuff, $0.62 for chewing tobacco, and $3.4875 for pipe tobacco. The excise tax rates on various tobacco products were amended, with pipe tobacco now taxed at $3.4875. These changes apply to products removed after December 31, 1995. The excise tax rates on tobacco products were amended, with pipe tobacco now taxed at $3.4875 per pound for products removed after December 31, 1995. Additionally, a tax of $1.86 per pound is imposed on roll-your-own tobacco manufactured or imported into the United States. In subsection (f), a new subsection (g) imposes a tax of $1.86 per pound on roll-your-own tobacco manufactured or imported into the United States. The term 'roll-your-own tobacco' is defined as any tobacco suitable for making cigarettes based on appearance, type, packaging, or labeling. The term 'roll-your-own tobacco' is defined as any tobacco suitable for making cigarettes based on appearance, type, packaging, or labeling. Amendments include adding roll-your-own tobacco to the definition in section 5702 of the Code. The definition of 'roll-your-own tobacco' is expanded to include it in the production regulations alongside cigars, cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, and pipe tobacco. The definition of 'roll-your-own tobacco' is expanded to include production for personal consumption, and the chapter heading for chapter 52 is amended. The chapter heading for chapter 52 on tobacco products and cigarette papers and tubes is amended in the table of chapters for subtitle E of the Code. The effective date for the amendments regarding roll-your-own tobacco under chapter 52 is after December 31, 1995. On December 31, 1995, a transitional rule allows individuals engaged in the manufacturing or importing of tobacco products to continue their business if they submit an application before January 1, 1996. Before January 1, 1996, individuals can continue their tobacco business if they submit an application under chapter 52 of the Code. All provisions of chapter 52 apply to the applicant as if they already hold a permit. On cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco manufactured in or imported into the United States before January 1, 1996, taxes will be imposed on such products held for sale by any person. For tobacco products held for sale before January 1, 1996 in the United States, the following taxes apply:
(A) Small cigars: $4.6875 per thousand for cigars weighing not more than 3 pounds per thousand.
(B) Large cigars: 53.125% of the price for which sold, not exceeding $125 per thousand for cigars weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand.
(C) Small cigarettes: $50 per thousand for cigarettes weighing not more than 3 pounds per thousand. (C) Small cigarettes: $50 per thousand for cigarettes weighing not more than 3 pounds per thousand.
(D) Large cigarettes: $105 per thousand for cigarettes weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand; if over 6.5 inches in length, taxed at the rate for smaller cigarettes. The tax rates for cigarettes vary based on weight and size. Small cigarettes weighing not more than 3 pounds per thousand are taxed at $50 per thousand. Large cigarettes weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand are taxed at $105 per thousand, but if they are over 6.5 inches in length, they are taxed at the rate for smaller cigarettes. Cigarette papers are taxed at 3.125 cents for each 50 papers, while cigarette tubes are taxed at 6.25. The tax rates for cigarette tubes and snuff are specified based on their length and weight. Cigarette tubes are taxed at 6.25 cents for each 50 tubes, with an additional charge for tubes over 6.5 inches in length. Snuff is taxed at $1.50 per pound. The tax rates for tobacco products are specified based on their type and weight. Cigarette tubes are taxed at a rate counting each 2/3 inches as one tube, while snuff is taxed at $1.50 per pound. Chewing tobacco is taxed at 50 cents per pound, and pipe tobacco at $2.8125 per pound. The tax rates for tobacco products vary based on type and weight. Pipe tobacco is taxed at $2.8125 per pound, with a proportional tax on fractional parts. Anyone holding taxed tobacco products on January 1, 1996, is liable for the tax. On January 1, 1996, tobacco products subject to tax must pay by February 15, 1996, following the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Tobacco products subject to tax must be paid by February 15, 1996, following the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The terms for cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco are defined in this subsection. The terms for cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco are defined in this subsection according to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Taxes imposed on these products do not apply to retail stocks. The taxes imposed on cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, cigarette tubes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco do not apply to retail stocks held on January 1, 1996. Additionally, these products in foreign trade zones are exempt from federal taxes. The Act of June 18, 1934 exempts certain tobacco products from federal taxes if determined by a customs officer before January 1, 1996. Certain tobacco products exempt from federal taxes if determined by a customs officer before January 1, 1996, and entered into the US from a foreign trade zone. Certain tobacco products, including cigars, cigarettes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco, are exempt from federal taxes if supervised by a customs officer before January 1, 1996, and entered into the US from a foreign trade zone. Certain tobacco products, like cigars, cigarettes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco, entering the US from a foreign trade zone after January 1, 1996, will be subject to federal taxes. A trust fund is established under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for this purpose. The establishment of a Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund under SEC. 9512 is outlined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for certain tobacco products entering the US from foreign trade zones after January 1, 1996. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund, established under SEC. 9512 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, consists of amounts appropriated or credited to it. The Secretary transfers 3 percent of the net revenue increase to the Trust Fund from the Treasury due to specified tobacco-related amendments. The Trust Fund receives 3 percent of revenue increase from specified tobacco-related amendments for assisting farmers in transitioning from tobacco to other crops and improving market access. The Trust Fund receives 3 percent of revenue increase from specified tobacco-related amendments to assist farmers in transitioning to other crops and improving market access. Appropriation Acts provide assistance to farmers converting from tobacco to other crops and support economic diversification plans for communities and individuals involved in tobacco production. The assistance mentioned includes government purchase of tobacco allotments to support economic diversification plans for communities and individuals involved in tobacco production. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for the subchapter. The text chunk "Sec. 9512. Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund." is a section related to the establishment of a fund for the conversion of tobacco production to support economic diversification plans.
